newsitem.title: USA: VLSI to supply chip in Microsoft project.
newsitem.headline: VLSI to supply chip in Microsoft project.

text.p: VLSI Technology Inc on Thursday said its chip for securing data distributed over networks has been selected as a core technology in personal computers being designed specifically for entertainment and electronic commerce.

The PCs are to be developed through an industrywide initiative launched by Microsoft Corp. VLSI officials said the company's soon-to-be-released GhostRider chip will perform security functions in the equipment under development.

Earlier Microsoft announced an effort involving three dozen companies to develop a personal computer that combines television, Internet and PC technologies. Microsoft and VSLI said they hoped the PCs would become available in retail outlets by late this year.
"We want this market to jump quickly, but it depends on how quickly consumers adapt," Umesh Padval, vice president of VSLI's computing solutions group, told Reuters.

"We developed the chip and are working with Microsoft and some of the PC and add-in card makers to get it integrated into their systems," said Padval. "We will supply hardware security to the systems providers."

Neil Shea, VLSI's director of its secure products group, said the GhostRider -- to be formally introduced this month -- is one of two chips for handling security that the company plans to bring to market this year. The second is for controlling distribution of digital entertainment.

Microsoft last year launched its "Simply Interactive PC" initiative to create a set of technologies consisting of broadcast components that would allow PCs to receive television programming, data services and new forms of entertainment that blend the two.
This week Microsoft renewed that effort by announcing partners and a set of new user interface elements for its Windows operating system that would allow for the new PCs.
Systems manufacturers participating in Microsoft's intitiative include Compaq Computer Corp, Gateway 2000 Inc, Hitachi Ltd, Fujitsu Ltd and Sony Electronics Inc.
